issue.title: coala -A throws exception on EOF signal
issue.body:
Overview Description
Sending EOF signal to coala -A results in EOFError
Steps to Reproduce

run coala with -A or --single-action flag
press Ctrl-D(EOF signal)
EOFError is dumped to the console

Actual Results
EOFError is dumped on console with the following traceback
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/amol/anaconda3/envs/coala/bin/coala", line 11, in <module>
    load_entry_point('coala', 'console_scripts', 'coala')()
  File "/home/amol/GitHub/coala/coalib/coala.py", line 121, in main
    return mode_normal(console_printer, None, args, debug=debug)
  File "/home/amol/GitHub/coala/coalib/coala_modes.py", line 29, in mode_normal
    debug=debug)
  File "/home/amol/GitHub/coala/coalib/coala_main.py", line 116, in run_coala
    choice = input(line)
EOFError

Expected Results
A better message like, Found EOF. Exiting gracefully. should be shown and the process must exit with status code 0
Reproducibility
100%
Additional Information:
difficulty/low
coala/main

issue.title: Development setup notes: 'installing from git' link can be optimised to not reload the page
issue.body:
The link reloads the entire page and doesn't even redirect to the required location
Instead it should just be '#installing-from-git'

issue.body:
coala_main.py, coalib/core/Core.py, setup.py, and some other files exceed the line length limit according to PEP8 standard.
Some of them can possibly be solved by adjusting the imports and docstrings.

issue.title: Add linter bear type 'json'
issue.body:
Many linters now emit json, and we have regular bugs when a linter is emitting json but also emits an error message on stdout.
The loading of the json can be done in coala with appropriate error checking and logging of any problems.
Also if the json is empty, the bear .run doesnt need to be invoked.

issue.title: ShowPatchAction: Make patches better readable
issue.body:
Currently no context lines are displayed, which makes it very hard to grasp simple code relocations. E.g. coala proposed following patch (I added unified-diff-like markers because coala just colors added and deleted lines, it doesn't show + and -):
[----] /app/etc/test.json
[++++] /app/etc/test.json
[  18]+         "xray": {
[  19]+             "package": [
[  20]+                 "com.example.xray"
[  21]+             ],
[  22]+             "value": 33.33
[  23]+         },
[  23]-         },
[  24]-         "xray": {
[  25]-             "package": [
[  26]-                 "com.example.xray"
[  27]-             ],
[  28]-             "value": 33.33

I just relocated the xray entry, but it's really hard to see that (look at the line numbers). Esp. you have a problem to check where it is exactly located. You can only see the line numbers, open your editor, navigate to those lines, and check up if the position is correct and doesn't produce invalid JSON.
This is not acceptable and coala has to print better diffs here showing a few context lines like git does.

issue.title: Section: Set files to ignore list from another section
issue.body:
It is quite common to have two sections with opposite sets of files included.
e.g. one section might use line length = 80 and the other section uses 120
At the moment, to do this requires listing the same files twice.

issue.title: Nextgen-Core: Raise exception in core.run() when bear or result-callback raised an exception
issue.body:
Currently the core properly cleans up the failing bear and discards all dependent tasks and bears, and then swallows the exception.
However, coala (and other users) needs to know that something didn't work perfectly, for example returning an error code that some analysis was run, but couldn't complete due to errors.
I propose to write a custom exception that aggregates all those swallowed exceptions and is then raised in core.run().
class Exceptions(Exception):
    def __init__(self, exceptions):
        super().__init__('Multiple exceptions happened:\n' + '\n\n'.join(str(ex) for ex in exceptions)
        self.exceptions = exceptions
To make use of it, the core Session has another field, e.g. self.silent_errors or self.recovered_errors (or similar), where all components can put in their errors if they can recover from them. When exiting the run, the Session checks if exceptions were placed into self.silent_errors/self.recovered_errors, constructs an Exceptions instance with all of those errors and raises it in the main thread.
Acceptance criteria:

An exception is implemented that is capable of storing multiple exceptions and emitting an appropriate error message
core.run() raises this exception if at least one bear or result-callback failed. The raised exception provides information on all exceptions occurred and swallowed inside core.run().

comments.bodyText:
Before the changes,

Context lines are now displayed.

The printing of the patch was handled by print_beautified_diff . This function took difflib.unified_diff as its input.  But difflib.unified_diff had n=3 which is the default number of context lines that will be supplied.
The print_beautified_diff took care of printing the affected lines but it did not print the normal context lines.

@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+Testing coala change on coala-bears
+===================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+There was an attempt to automate this through
+https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/4424 which used to depend upon docker
+image, but unfortunately the image breaks stuff for now.
+
+But we can still do it manually, by changing the coala dependency for the
+bears to be the one consisting of the changes made For which we need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, edit the requirements and run it on CI.
+
+Set-up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming we have already made changes to coala through a new branch, we can
+use the branch to install coala instead of master by editing requirements.txt
+file in coala-bears. So, lets set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these
+changes.
+
+If you have not already, clone your fork by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/coala-bears
+
+Make sure that you replace <your-username> with your corresponding github
+username.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch (other than master).
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    See `Git Tutorial <https://coala.io/gitbasics>`_ for more info.
+
+Now you've done that, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First thing we need is to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch <branch-name>, you
+can edit the coala dependency by changing the corresponding line to:
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+Set-up CI to run on your branch
+-------------------------------
+
+Since you need the tests to be ran on CI, set it up by modifying respective
+configuration files. You can have a look at our
+`CI Tutorial <https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Adding_CI.html>`_.
+for more info.
+
+For example, to run `travis-ci <https://travis-ci.org/>`_ on your
+branch you could modify .travis.yml file. At the end of the file, you'll find
+branch specification where you could white-list your branch name. So you should
+have the change as following:
+
+::
+
+    branches:
+      only:
+        - new_test_branch
+
+Simillarly, you can make changes to appveyor.yml file to run tests on AppveyorCI

@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+Testing coala change on coala-bears
+===================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+There was an attempt to automate this through
+https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/4424 which used to depend upon docker
+image, but unfortunately the image breaks stuff for now.
+
+But we can still do it manually, by changing the coala dependency for the
+bears to be the one consisting of the changes made For which we need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, edit the requirements and run it on CI.
+
+Set-up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming we have already made changes to coala through a new branch, we can
+use the branch to install coala instead of master by editing requirements.txt
+file in coala-bears. So, lets set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these
+changes.
+
+If you have not already, clone your fork by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/coala-bears
+
+Make sure that you replace <your-username> with your corresponding github
+username.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch (other than master).
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    See `Git Tutorial <https://coala.io/gitbasics>`_ for more info.
+
+Now you've done that, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First thing we need is to change the coala dependency.

@@ -0,0 +1,101 @@
+Testing changes to coala on coala-bears
+=======================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+You can do this by changing the coala dependency for the bears to
+be the one consisting of the changes. In order to do this, you need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, update the coala requirement to point to your
+changes and run CI on it.
+
+Set up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming you have already made changes to coala through a new branch, you can
+use that branch to install coala by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+Let's set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these changes:
+
+If you have not already, clone the coala-bears repository by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone -o upstream https://github.com/coala/coala-bears
+
+.. note::
+    ``-o upstream`` sets the remote name of the original coala-bears repository
+    as upstream.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+This tutorial assumes you are working on your own fork. To fork the repository,
+go to the official repository of coala-bears and click on the ``Fork``
+button from the website interface. To add it locally, simply run:
+
+::
+
+    $ git remote add myfork fork_link
+
+where ``myfork`` is the name of your fork, and ``fork_link`` is a link to your
+fork repository.
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch.
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+Here ``new_test_branch`` is the name of the new branch you created. You can
+use any name you want for this purpose.
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,101 @@
+Testing changes to coala on coala-bears
+=======================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+You can do this by changing the coala dependency for the bears to
+be the one consisting of the changes. In order to do this, you need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, update the coala requirement to point to your
+changes and run CI on it.
+
+Set up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming you have already made changes to coala through a new branch, you can
+use that branch to install coala by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+Let's set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these changes:
+
+If you have not already, clone the coala-bears repository by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone -o upstream https://github.com/coala/coala-bears
+
+.. note::
+    ``-o upstream`` sets the remote name of the original coala-bears repository
+    as upstream.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+This tutorial assumes you are working on your own fork. To fork the repository,
+go to the official repository of coala-bears and click on the ``Fork``
+button from the website interface. To add it locally, simply run:
+
+::
+
+    $ git remote add myfork fork_link
+
+where ``myfork`` is the name of your fork, and ``fork_link`` is a link to your
+fork repository.
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch.
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+Here ``new_test_branch`` is the name of the new branch you created. You can
+use any name you want for this purpose.
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    Please go through our `Newcomers Guide <https://coala.io/newcomer>`_ if
+    you are new to coala.
+
+Now that you're on a new branch, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First, you need to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now, assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch ``<branch-name>``,
+you can edit the coala dependency by editing requirements.txt in coala-bears.
+To do this, you need to edit the line in requirements.txt corresponding to:
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/coala/coala#egg=coala
+
+and change it to :
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+This will ensure that the coala will be installed using the source from the
+branch consisting of your changes to coala.
+
+Commit and push changes
+-----------------------
+
+You have now made the required changes to the bears repository, you are free
+to commit the changes and push the branch.

issue.title: coala_main.py: Changes Ctrl-Z to Ctrl-Z-Enter
issue.body:
Fixes #5254

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText: Ctrl-Z-Enter would look like we need to press all the 3 keys simultaneously. But iirc, The proper way to send an EOF signal in Windows is to press Ctrl-Z followed by Enter. So something like, Ctrl-Z followed by Enter would seem more appropriate.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ def do_nothing(*args):
 
 
 STR_ENTER_LETTER = 'Enter letter (Ctrl-{} to exit): '.format(
-    'Z' if platform.system() == 'Windows' else 'D')
+    'Z-Enter' if platform.system() == 'Windows' else 'D')
